author: Jen
title: Government may give out free sanitary products to poor pupils
text:
Sanitary products can be expensive (Picture: Rex) The government is considering giving out free tampons and pads to girls struggling to afford them. 
Education Secretary Justine Greening said she would ‘look carefully’ at the issue, after a charity highlighted that some pupils were resorting to using socks because they couldn’t afford sanitary products, and missing lessons.
Here's what's banned on some planes as part of new UK flight restrictions Some schools have been so concerned that they asked a charity to supply sanitary products to them in the same way they do for women in Kenya.
Following media attention, Leeds North West MP Greg Mulholland raised the issue in the House of Commons.
‘It’s deeply shocking in the 21st century that girls, including in Leeds, are not going to school because they can’t afford sanitary products,’ he said during education questions on Monday.
Ms Greening replied: ‘I think you have raised an important issue and it’s one that I will look at carefully and write to you about.’

It comes as more than 40,000 people signed a petition for UK schools to provide sanitary products for free.
Primark issues urgent recall over leggings that could be deadly ‘Children in the UK are missing school because they are unable to afford sanitary products, with some being absent for a week every month. This has enormous effect on their education and future job prospects,’ it reads.
‘We call on the Education Secretary, Justine Greening, to make sure sanitary products are free in schools across the UK schools.’
The issue came to light after the charity Freedom4Girls said schools had asked them to help.
One girl who started her period aged 11 told the BBC: ‘I wrapped a sock around my underwear just to stop the bleeding, because I didn’t want to get shouted at. And I wrapped a whole tissue roll around my underwear, just to keep my underwear dry until I got home. I once Sellotaped tissue to my underwear. I didn’t know what else to do.
(Picture: Getty) ‘I kept this secret up until I was 14 years old and then I started asking for help.
Girl, 15, sexually assaulted by 6 men on Facebook Live - but nobody reported to police ‘I didn’t get any money because my mum was a single parent and she had five mouths to feed, so there wasn’t much leftover money in the pot to be giving to us.’
New York passed legislation last year to provide free menstrual products to women and girls in schools, prison and homeless shelters, saying that they are a necessity, not a luxury.
Tina Leslie, from, Freedom4Girls has launched a GoFundMe page to raise money for a nationwide study on the issue.
